extracted_information: Detailed color contrast requirements based on WCAG 2.0 and WCAG 2.1, including specific ratios for AA and AAA compliance, definitions for large text, and methods/considerations for testing various elements.

specifications.contrast_ratio_definition: A measure of the difference in perceived luminance or brightness between two colors, expressed as a ratio ranging from 1:1 (e.g., white on white) to 21:1 (e.g., black on white).

large_text_definition.points: 18pt and larger, or 14pt and larger if it is bold.
large_text_definition.pixels: 18pt maps to 24 pixels, 14pt maps to approximately 18.67 pixels.

exceptions: Incidental (inactive user interface component, pure decoration, not visible, or part of a picture with significant other visual content)
Logotypes (text part of a logo or brand name)

applies_to: User Interface Components (visual information required to identify components and states)
Graphical Objects (parts of graphics required to understand the content)
exceptions: Where the appearance of the component is determined by the user agent and not modified by the author
When a particular presentation of graphics is essential to the information being conveyed (e.g., heat maps, real-life imagery, logos)

features.description: Visual presentation of text and images of text must have a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, with an exception for large text which requires 3:1. Exceptions also include incidental text/images and logotypes.
testing_considerations: Applies to text within graphics (images of text).
Text effects like outlines or halos can impact perceived contrast; outline color can be text color, halo color can be background color for measurement.
For text over gradients, semi-transparent colors, and background images, test the area where contrast is lowest.
Text in interactive states (hover, focus, active) must meet contrast requirements independently and be evaluated in each state.

features.description: More stringent contrast requirements than Level AA: 7:1 for normal text and 4.5:1 for large text. Although higher contrast is recommended, Level AA is the common legal requirement.

Requires visual information for user interface components and graphical objects to have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1 against adjacent colors. This means contrast may need to be measured in multiple places (e.g., different sides of an element or between its internal components).
specific_applications: User Interface Components: Controls for distinct functions, including each state (e.g., hover, focus) must have 3:1 contrast.
Graphical Objects: Elements 'required to understand the content' must meet 3:1 contrast. If descriptive text is present, the graphical object may be exempt.

features.description: Prohibits using color alone as the only visual means of conveying information, indicating an action, prompting a response, or distinguishing a visual element. Additional visual cues (e.g., text labels, icons, underlines) must be provided.
features.application_to_links:
When color is the only way to identify a link (e.g., underline removed from body text links): 
  1. Must have 3:1 contrast between the body text and the link text. 
  2. A visual cue (not just a color change) must appear on keyboard focus (and recommended mouse hover), typically an underline. 
  These conditions are in addition to the 4.5:1 contrast requirement for the link text with its background.
